bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, August 9, 1929

div1.p: Carter is back in Washington, D.C. and is ready to resume work as soon as Frost calls her. She describes work she accomplished during her vacation on the outline maps for the manuscript of the History of Yellow Fever.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, August 9, 1929
div1.opener:
Book, Misel
Report Russell
Carbon copy for [unclear]
please return or
forward to
Henry & Nelson.
[unclear] L.
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
August 9, 1929.
Dear Doctor Russell:
div1.p:
I have the honor to report my return to Washington on
Wednesday, August 7th., having heard from Mrs. Frost last Saturday
that Dr. Frost would return to Baltimore at or about, this time. I called up
Dr. Frost's residence, by long distance, the night of my arrival
to announce my return and my instant availability for work in con-
nection with the final editing of the History of Yellow Fever. Dr.
Frost stated that he was not yet quite ready to resume this work, but
that he hoped to do so in the very near future and that he would ad-
vise me as soon as he could set a tentative date therefor.

In the interim. I shall (a) once more go over the remaining 3/5
of Father's MS, yet to be edited, so as to be properly saturated with
its technicalities when we return to it: (b) Once more collect from
the Library of the Surgeon General of the Army and the Library of Con-
gress such books as Dr. Frost will certainly need for his remaining work
on the MS--Brinton's Maya Chronicles; Lind: Schotte etc. These are
sometimes quite hard to secure and I do not want to lose any time by
not having them already “lined up.” (c) I shall also go over, and
probably add to, my rather extensive Memorandum re details in connection
with the actual completion of the book about which I wish to ask Dr.
Frost.

I am glad to say that I was able to do more work on the book
while at “Dunlora” thant I had anticipated (a) In collaboration, by cor-
cespondance, with Mr. Weckerley on the outline maps and (b) having the
good fortune to meet Mr. David I. Bushnell of the Smithsonian Institu-
Institu-
-2-
tion, who has offered to help me get all my illustrative material in
the best shape for reproduction as soon as the size of the book is
determined--i. e. octavo, quarto etc. The illustrations in Mr. Bush-
nells many publications on the American Indians etc. are particularly
good and I feel that with the help of the various men at the Smithso-
nian to whom he has promised to introduce me I should be able to turn
over this material to you in a very satisfactory form. This, of course,
would in no wise delay the time of the completion of the work on the
Ms., as I could attend to it over here during the intervals when Dr.
Frost does not need me (a) in Baltimore, for explanation of cards or
(b) at the Libraries here, in case he wishes more extensive data on
some references than I anticipated.

Miss Brown is, of course, ready and eagerly waiting to render
us all further assistance in her power on a volunteer basis.

With all manner of good wishes to yourself and most earnest
hopes that, on its resumption, the work will go through quickly and
without further interruption,
div1.closer:
Most truly yours, Laura A. Carter Dr. Frederick F. Russell,
Director,
International Health Division
The Rockefeller Foundation,
61 Broadway,
New York, N. Y.
P. S. I know that you all share my feelings in regard to poor
Mrs. Darling's loss of her oldest son. I have just received a very
heart-broken letter from her. Poor woman! She has suffered much--
and bravely!
Sorry indeed about Dr. Lewis' death from yellow fever and that of
the man in Liberia.
L.A.C.
